+Rebecca98463 Actually, Esperanto does have native speakers. They're called 
denaskoj in Esperanto. They're usually the offspring of two people who have 
no shared language other than Esperanto and thus usr the language at home, 
imparting it to their children. There are an estimated 1'000 denaskoj, 
including second and third generation native speakers. That's not many, but 
it's more than some endangered languages. So, as far as native speakers 
goes, Esperanto would be an endangered language. But add ~2'000'000 second 
language speakers of Esperanto and it becomes clear that this language 
isn't going anywhere any time soon.

comments.text:
+MageSutek What I meant was that Elvish as the language it was supposed to 
be has a limited and countable amount of (known) words, as it is not a 
language used by absolutely existing people. Words created by a single mind 
can be counted. There was at first only one word, after a year perhaps a 
thousand. I am developing an artificial language Dhelenoth, and I can count 
every word there is precisely.

A couple of years ago it was proven that languages do not develop in a 
social vacuum. I read an article about people found after having lived all 
or at least most their lives without contacts with other people. None of 
them had the thing what is called language.

Social intercourse means using a language. What animals do when in contact 
with one another, is also usage of language.

The reason I pointed out how your original comment couldn't be applied to 
Elvish languages is that those Elvish languages are not spoken. Their 
vocabulary has come from exactly one head. What fans have created 
afterwards is not a part of the Elven languages. After all, the legendarium 
was created by Mr Tolkien, not by his fans.

The number of words in a language is not countable. However, then we must 
say that Elven languages are not languages. Because the number of words in 
Elven languages can be precisely counted. Why? Because all the words there 
are exist on paper. New words cannot be found, because no person, who 
speaks these languages, lives. Elves are imaginary, in the same way their 
usage of the language is. 

Yes, I remember how you pointed out that 'dog' can be more than just one 
word. Well, when it comes to artificial languages, this number is clearly 
stated. If a certain word has more than one meaning, then it is mentioned, 
or otherwise no one can assume it has more than one meaning. For an 
example, in Dhelenoth, the word 'narlan' is both the noun 'love' and the 
infinitive 'to love'. Or to be more precise, Dhelenoth doesn't even have 
infinitives, as all verbs are, without exception, either conjugated or 
replaced with nouns, adjectives or adverbials. So I can say, quite clearly, 
that 'narlan' is at most 2 words, and if I go on with this on every single 
word there is in Dhelenoth, I can tell the exact maximum of words in 
Dhelenoth.

Of course, it depends on our theory of the language, whether or not we 
agree that Dhelenoth has I infinitives, but the only correct way to 
interpret the language is to say that there is none. Again, as Dhelenoth is

Pretty much in the same way I can say (truthfully) that the number of words 
in Dhelenoth is close to x. But if someone else says the number is 2-20 
times bigger than it really is, then of course that someone is wrong.

We don't even need to go into linguistics to be able to say that thousands 
is a bit exaggerating, when the real number is close to 600. It's simply

problem. Because Elven languages were born in one head, and the number of

comments.text:
+Jesse Heinonen I did not make a comparison between Elvish and English. I 
was only talking about English and how it relates to our understanding of 
word quantity in English, and by extension, every other language spoken on 
Earth. I would disagree to a large extent about languages being "born" of 
social intercourse. Human beings were using language long before they began 
interacting with one another socially. You are basing your supposition on a 
standard of thinking in linguistics called the "discontinuity theory." I am 
a "continuity theorist," and always have been. I often use the example of 
animals "speaking" to one another as a means of bolstering my claims. There 
is no right or wrong answer, but the two schools of thought are quite 
separate. As far as you mentioning "artificial languages," I cannot say I 
understand what you mean. Something is either a language or is not a 
language. "Structure," or what I assume you are referring to as morphology 
is not necessary for a language to be a language.

I would disagree with your assertion that the number of words in a language 
is quantifiable. You may want to reread my post. I think my thesis was 
fairly clear. We can, at best, guess at how many words there are in any 
given language. This is something that humanity has been struggling with 
since the first lexicographers attempted to quantify the body of language. 
It is an ever-expanding phenomenon, and therefore, it is really quite 
impossible to determine how many words count at the end when everything has 
been said and done. Language is in a constant state of flux. With respect 
to Elvish, as I mentioned in my first post, I cannot speak to the nuances 
of the language itself, but I will say that as long as there are people 
adding words to the language, it continues to expand, and is therefore not 
quantifiable. I would count the words being developed by "fans." Certainly 
the Tolkien family has. Who are we to impose? As long as people are 
continuing the evolution of Tolkien's work, his languages will continue to 
evolve and change.

Just because Tolkien is dead does not mean his languages died with him. If 
we were to dismiss evolutionary linguistics on account of someone dying, we 
would not have a modern English to speak of; Shakespeare, Chaucer, 
Beowulf's writer, and the Earth's most primitive cavemen all have legacies: 
their contribution to language as we know it today. If we stuck with the 
premise that since Shakespeare and Chaucer are no longer writing, and 
everything subsequent is null because it not in their hand, we would never 
have evolved out of Old English.

comments.text:
I cannot speak to Elvish or Klingon, but I will say that with English, 
asking how many words are in the language, there is no single sensible 
answer to the question. It is impossible to count the number of words in a 
language, because it is so hard to decide what actually counts as a word. 
Is the word "dog" one word or two (a noun meaning "a kind of animal" and a 
verb meaning "to follow persistently")? It is also difficult to decide what 
counts as "English." What about medical and scientific terms? Latin words 
used in law, French words used in cooking, German words used in academic 
writing, Japanese words used in martial arts? Do you count Scots dialect? 
Teenage slang? Abbreviations?

The Second Edition of the 20-volume Oxford English Dictionary contains full 
entries for 171,476 words in current use, and 47,156 obsolete words. To 
this may be added around 9,500 derivative words included as sub-entries. 
Over half of these words are nouns, about a quarter adjectives, and about a 
seventh verbs; the rest is made up of exclamations, conjunctions, 
prepositions, suffixes, et cetera. And these figures do not take into 
account entries with senses for different word classes (such as nouns and 
adjectives).

This suggests that there are, at the very least, a quarter of a million 
distinct English words, excluding inflections, and words from technical and 
regional vocabulary not covered by the OED, or words not yet added to the 
published dictionary, of which perhaps 20 per cent are no longer in current 
use. If distinct senses were counted, the total would probably approach 
three quarters of a million. #psycholinguistics    #historicallinguistics   
#theorecticallinguistics

captions.text:
To many, one of the coolest things
about "Game of Thrones"

is that the inhabitants
of the Dothraki Sea
have their own real language.
And Dothraki came hot on the heels

of the real language
that the Na'vi speak in "Avatar,"
which, surely, the Na'vi needed

when the Klingons in "Star Trek" have had
their own whole language since 1979.
And let's not forget the Elvish languages

in J.R.R. Tolkien's
"Lord of the Rings" trilogy,

especially since that was
the official grandfather
of the fantasy conlangs.

"Conlang" is short for
"constructed language."
They're more than codes like Pig Latin,

and they're not just collections
of fabricated slang like the Nadsat lingo

that the teen hoodlums
in "A Clockwork Orange" speak,

where "droog" from Russian
happens to mean "friend."

What makes conlangs real languages
isn't the number of words they have.

It helps, of course,
to have a lot of words.
Dothraki has thousands of words.
Na'vi started with 1,500 words.

Fans on websites
have steadily created more.

But we can see the difference
between vocabulary alone
and what makes a real language

from a look at how Tolkien
put together grand old Elvish,
a conlang with several thousands words.

After all, you could memorize
5,000 words of Russian

and still be barely able
to construct a sentence.

A four-year-old would talk
rings around you.

That's because you have to know
how to put the words together.
That is, a real language has grammar.
Elvish does.

In English, to make a verb past,
you add an "-ed."
Wash, washed.
In Elvish, "wash" is "allu"
and "washed" is "allune."
Real languages also change over time.
There's no such thing as a language

that's the same today
as it was a thousand years ago.

As people speak, they drift
into new habits,
shed old ones,
make mistakes, and get creative.
Today, one says,
"Give us today our daily bread."
In Old English, they said,

"Urne gedaeghwamlican
hlaf syle us todaeg."
Things change in conlangs, too.

Tolkien charted out ancient
and newer versions of Elvish.
When the first Elves awoke at Cuiviénen,
in their new language,
the word for "people" was "kwendi,"

but in the language of one of the groups
that moved away, Teleri,
over time, "kwendi" became "pendi,"
with the "k" turning into a "p."

And just like real languages,
conlangs like Elvish split off into many.

When the Romans transplanted
Latin across Europe,
French, Spanish, and Italian were born.
When groups move to different places,

over time, their ways
of speaking grow apart,
just like everything else about them.
Thus, Latin's word for hand was "manus,"
but in French, it became "main,"
while in Spain it became "mano."

Tolkien made sure Elvish
did the same kind of thing.

While that original word
"kwendi" became "pendi"
among the Teleri,

among the Avari, who spread
throughout Middle Earth,

it became "kindi"
when the "w" dropped out.

The Elvish varieties Tolkien
fleshed out the most
are Quenya and Sindarin,

and their words are different
in the same way French and Spanish are.
Quenya has "suc" for "drink,"
Sindarin has "sog."
And as you know, real languages are messy.
That's because they change,

and change has a way
of working against order,

just like in a living room
or on a bookshelf.

Real languages are never
perfectly logical.

That's why Tolkien made sure
that Elvish had plenty of exceptions.

Lots of verbs are conjugated
in ways you just have to know.
Take even the word "know."
In the past, it's "knew,"

which isn't explained
by any of the rules in English.
Oh well.
In Elvish, "know" is "ista,"
but "knew" is "sinte."
Oh well.

The truth is, though, that Elvish
is more a sketch for a real language
than a whole one.
For Tolkien, Elvish was a hobby

rather than an attempt to create something
people could actually speak.

Much of the Elvish the characters
in the "Lord of the Rings" movies speak

has been made up since Tolkien
by dedicated fans of Elvish

based on guesses as to what Tolkien
would have constructed.

That's the best we can do for Elvish
because there are no actual Elves around
to speak it for us.
But the modern conlangs go further.

Dothraki, Na'vi, and Klingon
are developed enough
that you can actually speak them.

Here's a translation
of "Hamlet" into Klingon,

although performing it
would mean getting used
to pronouncing "k" with your uvula,

that weird, cartoony thing hanging
in the back of your throat.

Believe it or not, you actually do that
in plenty of languages around the world,
like Eskimo ones.
Pronouncing Elvish is much easier, though.
So, let's take our leave for now

from this introduction
to conlangs in Elvish
and the other three conlangs discussed

with a heartfelt
quad-conlangual valedictory:
"A Na Marie!"
"Hajas!"
Na'vi's "Kiyevame!"
"Qapla!"
and "Goodbye!"

title: Are Elvish, Klingon, Dothraki and Na'vi real languages? - John McWhorter
